sections.title: Syntax
sections.raw_content:
An includeConstruct is:

  include fileName

sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: An include is used to copy parts of files so that they become part of the Turing program. This copying is temporary, that is, no files are changed. The file name must be an explicit string constant such as "stdstuff".
sections.mdown_content: An **include** is used to copy parts of  files so that they become part of the Turing program. This copying is temporary, that is, no files are changed. The file name must be an explicit string constant such as "stdstuff".

sections.title: Example
code:
const upArrow := 200
        const downArrow := 208
        const rightArrow := 205
        const leftArrow := 203

include "arrows"
        
        var ch : string ( 1 )
        getch ( ch )                % Read one character
        case ord ( ch ) of
            label upArrow :
                handle up arrow
            label downArrow :
                handle down arrow
            label rightArrow :
                handle right arrow
            label leftArrow :
                handle left arrow
            label :
                handle any other key
        end case

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
An include file can itself contain include constructs. This can continue to any level, although a circular pattern of includes would be a mistake, as it would lead to an infinitely long program.

It is common to save procedures, functions and modules in separate files. The files are collected together using include.
sections.mdown_content:
An include file can itself contain **include** constructs. This can continue to any level, although a circular pattern of includes would be a mistake, as it would lead to an infinitely long program.
It is common to save procedures, functions and modules in separate files. The files are collected together using **include**.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: If the filename in the include statement starts with a "%", then Turing searches the system directory for the file. See the editor reference for the environment to see how to set the system directory. This method can be used to allow the system administrator to easily supply a set of routines in a file to a large number of users by placing it in one easy-to-find location.

See the editor reference for the environment to see how to set the system directory. This method can be used to allow the system administrator to easily supply a set of routines in a file to a large number of users by placing it in one easy-to-find location.

sections.title: Example
sections.raw_content:
If the system directory is set to "C:\TURING", then the line

will include the file "C:\TURING\SORTING.T" in the program.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: Under OOT, there are several system directories available. The "%oot" directory is the directory where all the OOT system files are located. The "%home" directory is the user's home directory.
sections.mdown_content: Under OOT, there are several system directories available. The "%oot" directory is the directory where all the OOT system files are located. The "%home" directory is the user's home directory.

sections.title: Example
sections.raw_content:
If the oot directory is set to "/usr/local/lib/oot" then the line

will include the file "/usr/local/lib/oot/teacher/sorting.t" in the program.
